description: This is a kit for a simple trap consisting of a rope noose and a snare trigger.  It requires a tree nearby.  It is effective at trapping monsters.
This is a kit for a simple trap consisting of a string noose and a snare trigger.  It requires a young tree nearby.  It is effective at trapping and killing some small animals.
This is a stick that has been cut into a trigger mechanism for a snare trap.
This is a farming implement made with a broad stone blade, that can be used to till earth.
A simple pulk sled and folded framework that can hold a modest amount of gear, traditionally used to drag equipment across snowy terrain.

use_action.unfold_msg: You unfold and deploy the makeshift sled.

description: A traditional dugout boat made from logs burned and carved to shape, along with handmade oars.  Bulky as it is, it can still be picked up and carried by a reasonably fit person.  Use it to deploy and make ready.
This exists only to allow makeshift stills to provide distilling quality.
This exists only to allow rope and pulley lifters to provide some engineering qualities.
Some sticks and string with a leather tarp, to set up an improvised raincatcher.

use_action.done_message: You set up the raincatcher, waiting to collect water.

description: A small piece of treated animal hide, undergoing the chemical processes required to become leather.  You will be able to activate it to unroll and make use of it when it is done.

use_action.msg: You carefully unfold the tanning leather scrap and shake it clean.
use_action.not_ready_msg: The scrap of tanning leather isn't done yet.
use_action.//: Should be 9.6 hours, but I suspect the timing hasn't been updated yet.

description: A small piece of treated animal pelt, undergoing the chemical processes required to become fur.  You will be able to activate it to unroll and make use of it when it is done.

use_action.msg: You carefully unfold the tanning fur scrap and shake it clean.
use_action.not_ready_msg: The scrap of tanning fur isn't done yet.
use_action.//: Should be 9.6 hours, but I suspect the timing hasn't been updated yet.

description: This is a small clay container with a wick, an ancient form of oil lamp.  It does not provide much light, but it lasts a long time.  Use it to turn it on.

This is a small clay container with a wick, an ancient form of oil lamp.  It does not provide much light, but it lasts a long time.  It does not provide much light, but it lasts a long time.  It is turned on.  Use it to turn it off.
This is a small ceramic fire pot, with a lid and small holes for controlled airflow.  It can nurture a smoldering ember for a long time, to start fires without modern tools.

use_action.need_fire_msg: You need a lighter or fire to light this.
use_action.need_charges_msg: The ember carrier is out of tinder.

description: This is a small ceramic fire pot, with a lid and small holes for controlled airflow.  An ember is smoldering inside it, and can be used to start a campfire.
This is a ancient style of portable ceramic oven.  Use it to place on the ground, allowing you to keep a small fire safe from wind and rain.

This is a portable toolkit, consisting of a primitive knife for carving replacement parts, an adze for more heavy-duty wood cutting, and a patch of soft material for cleaning surfaces.  It can be used to repair certain items if supplied with pitch, though it isn't ideal for complex work.
A prehistoric woodworking tool, little more than a fine sharp blade tipping a makeshift bow drill.  It's rather limited in usage, primarily meant to be used on wood.

A simple form of primitive firemaking, little more than two pieces of wood with a groove worn into one of them, to light an ember through friction.  Starting a fire with this will be laborious and slow, but it's better than nothing.
This is a pseudo item.

A very large 25 liter earthenware pot, primarily meant for canning food via the water bath method, though it can cook normal foods just as well.  Canning foods with it will require a lot of water.  If you're only canning a couple of jars at a time, you'd fill it up with rocks or something to displace the water above the lids.
